body: @nswamy the above pr link you shared is for symbol. Where is the one for ndarray?
@zackchase could you approve once it's ready?
How did you create the project in vs?

This star button actually doesn't work. It only points to github front page.
Maybe we should replace star and fork with a standard "fork me on github" ribbon

I added logic to run installation tasks only if the diff between this branch and the mxnet's master branch contains install.md.

Note the installation_source_test task fails in Travis because my changes to `install-mxnet-osx-python.sh` needs to be merged.

Also @mli the Jenkins server couldn't clone this repo for some reason...can you help retrigger the build?
@piiswrong Can you review/merge this?
ok, I will have a try.

I use cmake to make vs project.

I knew.
```python
batch_size = 32
mod2 = mx.mod.Module(symbol=sym, label_names=None, context=mx.gpu())
mod2.bind(for_training=False, data_shapes=[('data', (batch_size,3,224,224))])
```

@piiswrong Thank you. I have tried export MXNET_CUDNN_AUTOTUNE_DEFAULT=0/1/2, but there are no effects. What's more, I also set engine type to different values, but things do not change. That's so strange. I don't know if the net structure matters. I found some other net structures have no such problem.

```bash
git bisect start
git bisect bad
git bisect good v0.8.0
```

to
`COMMAND echo "Running: OpWrapperGenerator.py $<TARGET_FILE:mxnet>"`

then regenerate the solution and paste the output here?

For kBadStorageID, you can just add an extra line before that line:
Const int kBadStorageID = 1;

Are you sure 04f49aace27a4f16d19cbea6afead7f4b070318c is a bad commit? It's directly after 0.8 release and didn't change anything related to speed

I suspect its this one: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/commit/9203e3857d05ae982907c75c894668047c51d4a8
see if reverting it helps

Merely stacking 4 tutorials together doesn't tell a consistent story. It should be reordered as below.

1. Introduce the interface with DataIter, DataBatch and DataDesc.
2. Introduce the built-in iterators. NDArrayIter, CSVIter, ImageRecordIter, ImageIter.
3. What if the built-in iters are not enough for you? Introduce how to write custom iters.
4. Introduce mx.image API. Write a very simple dataiter that loads and crops images (see imageIter code for example. Simplify it to the bare minimum)
5. What if loading individual images is slow? Introduce MXRecordIO. Show how to modify the previous custom iter to use recordio API
i know what's happening. some dependencies (probably blas or opencv) are missing. you need to register the dlls systemwide.

Hi @piiswrong , from the last time that we discussed the necessary of getting this standard feature for python users in #4965, I've made a new update that makes the early stopping callback class saves the checkpoint of the model when the early stopping happens. Would you please have a review of the codes when you got time? Thank you!

Detection works I've seen all fix bn gamma and beta so there should be no worry.
`fix_gamma` for `bn_data` is really not important if all bn params are fixed so it could be kept as the way it is trained.
Thanks again!

@tqchen You mean just change grad_req to 'add', and update every iter_size iterations. The gradients will auto zeroing every update(). like this:
mod.bind(data_shapes=.., label_shapes=.., grad_req='add')
mod.init_params(..)
mod.init_optimizer(..)
for epoch in range(total_epochs):
    cnt = 0
    for batch in train_iter:
        cnt += 1
        mod.forward_backward(batch)  # compute predictions
        if cnt % iter_size == 0:    # every iter_size iterations 
              mod.update()  # update parameters

it looks like it's linked both dynamically and statically in cmake. I'm not familiar with cmake, cc cmakelist author @cjolivier01

why linking static libmxnet to the shared one?

It could happen the first time you are using gpus.
Sometimes also happens when you compiled with GPU enabled opencv

I'll try but no promises. There are too many things I need to look at.
Try running your tutorials through beginners and see if they think its easy to understand.

I know what happened.. This issue is caused by cuda jit. I checked default configuration of Makefile, the gen_code option for nvcc doesn't contain CUDA compute 61 arch so every kernel is converted to compute 61 in runtime because my gpu arch is 61. As mentioned in https://groups.google.com/d/msg/arrayfire-users/D3RORyrvn4s/N7AoKueSCAAJ, the conversion takes in the order of minutes, which matches my observation. It works well after adding sm_61 to gen_code option.

@piiswrong cmake handles different cuda archs correctly. (https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/blob/master/cmake/Cuda.cmake) Do you think it's good idea to port that part to Makefile? I don't know how does pip release handle this problem, but as c++ users need to compile by themselves, it makes life easier to check gpu archs automatically.

If you mean the USE_OPENCV, it's already set to 1. 
Double check and rebuild the package and same error happened.

For atrous convolution you can use

```python
mx.sym.Convolution(data=net, num_filter=channels, kernel=filter_dimension, stride=stride, dilate=dilate)
```
where the `dilate` parameter specifies how wide the convolution kernel reaches.
Can you check with the latest commit? Your error log says it's 0.9.4 while the latest is on 0.9.5.

Hi all,

I'm looking at PyOpenCL and it could be a solution for MXNet. The challenge that I've observed so far is PyOpenCL requires installation of Intel Open CL SDK on user's machine (if they are running Intel Graphics Card).

An example shared by [Easy OpenCL with Python](http://www.drdobbs.com/open-source/easy-opencl-with-python/240162614?pgno=2) is that Gaston Hillar has demonstrated to use only 12 steps to build and deploy a kernel with PyOpenCL. I've tested his codes and it is working for me.

I wonder if MXNet would consider to support PyOpenCL?
Great to see this PR:)

The problem was finally solved!

I fixed the `CMakeLists.txt` like this.
```
# before
find_library(LIBMXNET NAMES mxnet PATHS ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/lib)

# After
file(COPY ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/lib DESTINATION ${PROJECT_BINARY_DIR}/)
# :
# :
find_library(LIBMXNET NAMES mxnet PATHS ${PROJECT_BINARY_DIR}/lib)
```
Thank you so much for your corporation, @piiswrong and @lx75249 !!!

My guess is you don't need to explicitly change the input of the second module to the output of the last module. `Seq_module.add()` simply chain that for you.

I don't think there is regularization term in loss function, but you can define weight decay through optimizer interface:

```python
model.fit(train_data=data_train,
          num_epoch=num_epoch,
          optimizer='sgd',
          optimizer_params={'learning_rate':learning_rate, 'momentum':0, 'wd':0.0001},
          initializer=mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34))
```
I am not sure if mod.update will zeros the gradient, so maybe gradient zero need to be done manually

@sneakerkg @ZihengJiang Added updated_grad flag to indicate whether this gradient has been updated by last backward call.
